newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy unions to meet Prodi on metalworkers on Fri.
newsitem.headline: Italy unions to meet Prodi on metalworkers on Fri.

text.p: Leaders of Italy's three big trade union federations will meet Prime Minister Romano Prodi on Friday to discuss a long-standing metal and engineering workers dispute.
"Friday's meeting will be between the unions and the government," CISL union federation leader Sergio D'Antoni told a news conference on Wednesday.
D'Antoni said whether the employers federation Confindustria later joined in the talks would depend on the outcome of the meeting between the unions and the government.
The unions had asked Prodi to intervene in the pay dispute, which has been dragging on since June.
In December, the government suggested that management give workers an average 200,000-lire per month pay increase.
Unions, which had been seeking a 230,000 lire increase, accepted the proposals but Federmeccanica, the sector's employers organisation, refused it as inflationary.
"We need the meeting to understand why the employers see the government's proposal as inflationary," D'Antoni said.
On Monday, the Bank of Italy cut the official discount rate to 6.75 percent from 7.50 percent after months of falling inflation.
"With the cut in interest rates, Federmeccanica's alibi on costs and inflation simply disappears," D'Antoni said.
The dispute, which involves some 1.7 million workers, is expected to set the tone for pay deals in a number of other Italian industrial sectors.

Metalworkers unions have already staged three one-day stoppages to press their claims, and leaders of Italy's main three union federations have threatened to call a general strike if management does not accept the government proposal.
